body: Michael Norman is a reporter on the metropolitan staff of The Times. By Michael Norman In the slums, as elsewhere, image is constantly at odds with reality. Here, for example, is a two-story eyesore ready for the wrecker and demolition ball. Once it was a post office, solid and busy. Then the Government closed it and scavengers came through,
title: GOLDEN BOYS OF THE GHETTO

body: Three Brooklyn men were arrested yesterday in the theft of $2 million from a midtown bank last month. The money was being transferred from the Republic National Bank of New York at 452 Fifth Avenue to the Korean Exchange Bank in Seoul. A total of $295,580 was recovered. Among those arrested by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents was an employee
title: 3 HELD IN THEFT OF $2 MILLION IN A SHIPMENT

body: A $225-a-week electrical maintenance worker in a Manhattan office building was announced yesterday as the sole winner of the $5 million prize in the New York State Nov. 14 Lotto drawing, the largest known lottery payoff in history. Although the winner, Louis Eisenberg, 53 years old, and his wife, Bernice, expect to remain in their

Among the allegations of misconduct, made by attorneys for the convicted man, is that there was a
title: JURORS' CONDUCT AT MURDER TRIAL TO BE STUDIED

body: Tomorrow is the eve of Samhain, the Celtic New Year, and two Irishmusic groups are in town to celebrate a day early. Appearing tonight at 8 at Town Hall will be De Danann, the acclaimed band that combines traditional music with music of its own, and three young performers who specialize in Irish dance music, and airs and traditional songs of
title: WEEKEND GUIDE; Friday; TOWN HALL IRISH NIGHT

body: From the far reaches of the Bronx to Brighton Beach in Brooklyn, he was the dramatic voice of the Depression. In the 1930's, his admirers said he was America's next Eugene O'Neill, a playwright of the poor whose lyricism could move people and mountains and maybe even the Government. Like his beleaguered characters, he also lived a life of
title: THEATER FRIENDS RECALL LIFE AND WORKS OF ODETS

body: The reapportionment of New York City Council districts was rejected yesterday by the United States Justice Department on the ground that it ''does not fairly reflect minority voting strength.'' The ruling further scrambled the city's voting calendar, made uncertain the status of the local legislators after their terms expire at the end of the year
title: U.S. REJECTS PLAN FOR REDISTRICTING NEW YORK COUNCIL; Text of U.S. letter, page B5.

body: Jeff Sparks, a p ioneer broadcaster and a ra dio and television official of the United Nations from 1947 unti l his retirement in 1968, died of a heart attack Wednesday at his home. He was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan. After leaving the United Nations, Mr. Sparks directed public relations at the American Museum of Natural History-Hayden
title: Jeff Sparks, Radio-TV Official With the U.N., Is Dead at 76

body: Positions of the four mayoral candidates on major issues are on page 42. title: KOCH IS OPTIMISTIC ON GAINING VICTORY IN BOTH PRIMARIES

body: A T the White House, President Reagan's advisers have carefully weighed the best way to react to the first major anti-Administration march protesting the budget cuts and labor policy. The labor ''solidarity'' demonstration, on Saturday, is expected to lure tens of thousands of demonstrators to Washington. Initially, Mr. Reagan's aides scheduled a
title: WASHINGTON TALK BRIEFING

body: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Mayor Koch, Representative Stephen J. Solarz of Brooklyn and other leaders denounced President Reagan's proposed $8.5 billion arms sale to Saudi Arabia last night before 800 people at Abraham Lincoln High School in Brooklyn's Brighton Beach section. The speakers' objections centered mainly on the Airborne Warning and
title: THE CITY; Speakers Assail Arms Sale Plan

body: Entering the last days of the 1981 primary campaign, candidates both familiar and not so familiar fanned out across New York City over the weekend to rouse a mostly languorous voting public. The summer campaign had not been as galvanizing as last year's races, which came against the backdrop of a Presidential election year. And as potential voters
title: AS PRIMARY CAMPAIGN WINDS DOWN, CANDIDATES GO WHERE THE VOTERS ARE

body: ''Don't be shy - getchyer red-hots!'' growled a short, stout grayhaired man behind the Nathan's counter on Surf Avenue in Coney Island. ''Step up!'' he barked. ''Getchyer franks, have your money ready, hot doggies here, all you can eat! Red-hots!'' He chanted on, a gruff survivor of the razzle-dazzle past, but his vigor seemed puzzling. None of his
title: BELEAGUERED CONEY ISLANDERS RALLY WITH SENSE OF AFFECTION; The Talk of Coney Island

body: The banshee wail of an ambulance, the song of its siren, is the stuff of awful visions. When it sounds on a street, mothers picture their children running in front of cars, wives see their husbands clutching chest and vena cava, the elderly envision broken hips, falls, cardiac arrest. The ambulance crews are the bearers of this bad news. Walter
title: About New York; AMBULANCE CORPSMEN TEND TO CITY'S PAINS

body: Norman J. Rosen says he has lived in the shadow of District Attorney Eugene Gold of Brooklyn for 12 years. He worked in a spacious office adjoining Mr. Gold's, preparing grant applications, drawing up a budget and, in his words, ''sitting in on'' the policy decisions. Now the 52-year-old executive assistant has emerged to run for the job of his
title: EXPERIENCE, OR LACK OF IT, IS THE ISSUE IN BROOKLYN'S DISTRICT ATTORNEY RACE

body: SEEGER SALUTES HUDSON Pete Seeger will perform at the South Street Seaport tonight at 8 in the finale of a long-running commemoration. Since last January, the Seaport has been celebrating the Hudson River and its heritage. It has conducted tours of mansions along the Hudson, for instance, and offered lectures about old river craft in conjunction
title: GOING OUT GUIDE

title: SIX FORMER PROSECUTORS CALL MISS HOLTZMAN UNSUITABLE

title: Weekender Guide; Friday; EGLEVSKY IN WESTBURY

body: The battle lines over New York City's budget were distinctly drawn yesterday, with differences centering both on how much to spend in the next year and on what to do with an anticipated surplus for the 1981 fiscal year that ends June 30. With the prospect of the first genuine budget surplus in years - one whose size is still in dispute - the City
title: HAPPY WARRIORS BATTLE ON CITY SURPLUS

body: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority, in a list that came to light yesterday, has designated what it calls the 69 stations most in need of repair in the New York City subway system. It has recommended a six-year program to renovate them, but financing for the bulk of the program, the Transit Authority said, has yet to be found. The City
title: AGENCY LISTS ITS 69 MOST DETERIORATED SUBWAY STATIONS

body: Edith Axelrod's former neighbors in Manhasset Hills, L.I., would not know what to make of her. ''I listen to country and western music, I date a lot of men who drive pickups and I go target shooting,'' said Mrs. Axelrod, who moved to Dallas eight years ago. ''I'm also into metaphysics. I leave my metaphysics class and go country dancing. But I
title: NEW YORKERS IN DALLAS: GETTING THEM ALL TOGETHER

body: With New York City's six public beaches officially opening for the summer today, the Department of Parks and Recreation took itself harshly to task for not having done enough in the past to keep the shoreline free of dirt, crime and vandalism. In an unusually blunt report on its management of more than 14 miles of beachfront, the department
title: CITY OFFICIALS TAKE STEPS TO KEEP UP BEACHES CLEANER

body: ABRAHAM TETENBAUM'S new play, ''Heat of Re-Entry,'' which opened Wednesday night at the Playwrights Horizons' Capital Theater in the Park in Flushing Meadows Park, Queens, is a space-y play about the Soviet space hero Yuri Gagarin and also about Soviet Jews living in our own Brighton Beach. There is undoubtedly a good play about each of them in
title: THEATER: 'HEAT OF RE-ENTRY' LINKS SOVIET JEWS AND SPACE

body: ''There's a thief in the house!'' the rabbi shouted, ''There's a ganef!'' A giggle. A chortle. A smile in the back row. And Rabbi Leonard W. Stern dutifully scanned the faces of the 30 hospital patients for the culprit, the one who made off with the matzoh, and who, according to the a tradition of the Passover seder, had the right to claim a prize
title: SEDER BRINGS WARMTH AND A BIT OF HUMOR TO PATIENTS

body: New York City's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs led a band of assistants into an electronic-games arcade in midtown Manhattan yesterday and announced that the establishment was unlicensed and should close. Amid a cacophony of blasts, beeps and whines, two of Commissioner Bruce C. Ratner's inspectors then taped shut the coin slots of more than 50
title: CITY MOVES TO SHUT UN LICENSED ARCADES

title: 18 WEST GERMANS, SEEKING AMITY, VISIT U.S. JEWS

body: f814 By JUDITH CUMMINGS Two fleets of New York City subway cars with the worst performance records have been quietly transferred to new routes. title: SHIFTING OF CARS FOR THE D LINE CALLED POLITICAL

body: Ten subway riders suffered minor injuries early this morning in Brooklyn when a D train derailed on the IND line near Kings Highway, the Transit Authority said. The train, which runs from Brighton Beach in Brooklyn to 205th Street in the Bronx, was just entering the Kings Highway station about 12:15 A.M. when one car left the tracks, a transit
title: 10 Subway Riders Hurt In Brooklyn Derailment
